title: Ranking the Biggest NBA Finals Carry Jobs
dek: Who carried their team to the finals with the least help?
prompt: What do you think is the biggest NBA finals carry-job in league history?

intro.value: Despite being a team sport, some NBA teams rely on a star to get them to the finals more than others. Did Giannis do it without help? Not really. Did MJ carry Pippen? Sometimes. Is LeBron amazing? Yes.

There are plenty of opinionated articles and videos debating this already. So I figured I would add my data-driven take to the mix. What do the data say about ranking the biggest finals carry jobs in NBA history?
The data say that LeBron’s (losing) effort with the 2018 Cavs reigns supreme.

value.caption: Artistic interpretation of LeBron James carrying Kyle Korver. Other teammates not pictured, but also carried.

intro.value: To answer this I used the all-in-one advanced stat RAPTOR WAR created by 538. But we can’t just measure who had the highest Wins Above Replacement in isolation since games and minutes played have an impact. It needs to be relative to the rest of the team who had the same opportunity.

explore.value: This chart shows a player’s RAPTOR WAR in the playoffs vs. their minutes played for every team in the NBA finals since 1977. Players with more uniform impact are clustered closer together, and those with stand out performances are higher and more separated.
The <button data-ts=DET-2005>2005 Pistons</button> represents the “no ‘I’ in team” philosophy.
The <button data-ts=CHI-1998>1998 Bulls</button> and the <button data-ts=LAL-2020>2020 Lakers</button> are prime examples of a dynamic duo.

And finally we have Duncan leading the <button data-ts=SAN-2003>2003 Spurs</button>, Wade with <button data-ts=MIA-2006>2006 Heat</button>, and LeBron basically every year, but notably with the <button data-ts=CLE-2018>2018 Cavs</button> representing the single-handed carry jobs.

shares.value: To rank the biggest carry jobs, I decided to look at the share of WAR amongst the top three players on a team. I could’ve picked any number of players to compare to (just the next best through the whole roster), but each has its drawbacks. Most great teams have at least two or three stars, with the rest filling in as role players, so three is the magic number.

annotations.text: Wade tops the list for finals winners, carrying the load with an aging Shaq
LeBron was just so good in Miami that even with other stars his numbers were crazy
Dirk’s final run often cited as a carry job, but the data prefer his first appearance
The biggest surprise here, Hakeem’s first title usually sits atop most lists
Less minutes for Giannis and some stellar support put this at the bottom

outro.value: To summarize: the data say that LeBron is Mr. Playoffs, and some of the most epic carry jobs were done by finals losers, who maybe just needed one more piece to the puzzle.

method.value: Data for this story came from 538. The analysis only included players with 150+ minutes played. There are a lot of metrics out there, and they can all be great and terrible. Quantity matters in the playoffs, so a cumulative stat was chosen.
